I’m Tyler Spears, and I’m 20 years old. I go to Georgetown College in Scott County, where I’m majoring in Art and minoring in Computer Science. I’m really like graphic design and want to work in the design field or open my own print shop after college. I like to be creative and bring ideas to life.
I’m also Adobe Illustrator certified, which has helped me in my design work. I enjoy learning new design techniques and exploring different creative styles.
Outside of school, I stay pretty active and social. I have played pickleball over the past few years and i have even won two tournaments. When I’m not playing pickleball i’m ussally playing viedo games or hanging out with my friends or my girlfriend if i’m not doing that then i’m most likly at work or school. I have three dogs named Sheba, Buddy and Cooper and a bird named kiwi.
I have also done quite a bit of traveling across the U.S.. I’ve been to places like Yellowstone, Niagara Falls, and Florida, but my favorite trip so far was definitely Discovery Cove in Florida, where I got to swim with dolphins which has been an unforgettable experience.
I have also worked at Penn Station for about three years, and I’m currently a manager there. I handle most of the everyday operations, solve problems on the fly, and help train new team members. It’s taught me a lot about leadership, teamwork, and communication.
I’m proud to be an Eagle Scout and also completed NYLT (National Youth Leadership Training) through Boy Scouts, which helped me develop strong leadership and problem-solving skills that I carry into school, work, and everyday life.
Thank you for reading my get to know me if you care to learn more about other stuff i have done i have articles and links to the things i like

The first problem we are going to look at is one from the chaper two homework.
ChessBoardWrite a program that creates a string that represents an 8×8 grid, using newline characters to separate lines. At each position of the grid there is either a space or a "#" character. The characters should form a chessboard. Passing this string to console.log should show something like this:# # # # # # # # # # # ## # # # # # # ## # # # # # # ## # # #When you have a program that generates this pattern, define a binding size = 8 and change the program so that it works for any size, outputting a grid of the given width and height.My AnswerExplanation of how the code works below
let size = 8;let board = "";for (let y = 0; y < size; y++) {for (let x = 0; x < size; x++) {if ((x + y) % 2 == 0) {board += " ";} else {board += "#";}}board += "\n";}console.log(board)ExplanationIn order to explain the code we will take it line by line first lets start withlet size = 8; this determines the size of the board so in this case it would be an 8x8 board if we changed the number to 9 it would become a 9x9 board and so on as that number changes.let board = "";This makes the board as a string that can be printed out. This allows the board start with empty charactersfor (let y = 0; y < size; y++) {for (let x = 0; x < size; x++) {if ((x + y) % 2 == 0) {board += " ";} else {board += "#";}}board += "\n";}console.log(board)

The second problem we are going to look at is from the chapter 3 homework
Bean countingYou can get the Nth character, or letter, from a string by writing [N] after the string (for example, string[2]). The resulting value will be a string containing only one character (for example, "b"). The first character has position 0, which causes the last one to be found at position string.length - 1. In other words, a two-character string has length 2, and its characters have positions 0 and 1.Write a function called countBs that takes a string as its only argument and returns a number that indicates how many uppercase B characters there are in the string.
Next, write a function called countChar that behaves like countBs, except it takes a second argument that indicates the character that is to be counted (rather than counting only uppercase B characters). Rewrite countBs to make use of this new function.
// Your code here.
console.log(countBs(“BOB”)); // → 2 console.log(countChar(“kakkerlak”, “k”)); // → 4
My AnswerExplanation of how the code works below
function countBs(str) { return countChar(str);}function countChar(str, charToCount = 'B') { let count = 0;for (let i = 0; i < str.length; i++) {if (str[i] === charToCount) {count++;}}return count;}console.log(countBs("BOB"))// → 2console.log(countChar("kakkerlak", "k"))// → 4 Explanationfunction countBs(str) {return countChar(str);}function countChar(str, charToCount = 'B') {let count = 0;for (let i = 0; i < str.length; i++) {if (str[i] === charToCount) {count++;}return count;}console.log(countBs("BOB"))console.log(countChar("kakkerlak", "k"))
